subject: Home & DIY
title: Why Bathrooms Need Bonding
description: A quick, practical guide to Why Bathrooms Need Bonding.

hook.text: A metal bathtub and a pipe two feet apart can carry different voltages. Touch both while wet and the current kills.

buildup.text: Faulty wiring, lightning, or utility faults can energize metal objects in your home at different voltage levels.

discovery.text: Equipotential bonding ties all metal objects in a bathroom to one ground‚Äîerasing voltage differences between them.

twist.text: Plastic pipes broke the bonding chain in modern plumbing. New code requires separate bonding wires to compensate.

climax.text: Most older bathrooms lack proper bonding. A simple copper wire connecting fixtures to the ground system fixes the risk.

punchline.text: Equal voltage everywhere means zero shock risk.

quiz.question: What does equipotential bonding in a bathroom prevent?
options: Voltage differences between metal objects that could cause electrocution
Water from conducting electricity through pipes
Static electricity buildup on metal surfaces
